awd_titl_txt: Apples to Apples: Comparing the Cores of Nearby Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
The centers of galaxies are home to unique interactions between stars, gas, and black holes. Such interactions are responsible for forming new stars, growing a galaxy's central supermassive black hole, and driving energetic outflows. However, the detailed physics behind them is still poorly understood. Though nearby and easily studied, the Milky Way's center is relatively quiet. Few stars are forming in this region, and the black hole is not active. Because of this, the Milky Way is not a representative example of the full suite of processes that occur in these environments. This project will make the first comparison of gas properties in the Milky Way center with those in a more active galaxy. This work will lead to advances in our understanding of how the physics of the gas in galaxy centers is linked to inflow and outflow processes. In addition, this work will support a partnership with a prison education program to develop and teach math-intensive astronomy courses that will prepare incarcerated students to be part of a STEM-literate workforce. 

A key area of investigation, and a priority identified in the 2010 Decadal Survey, is what goes on in galaxy centers: the interactions between stars, black holes and gas. Until recently there has only been one galaxy where these interactions can be investigated in detail: The Milky Way, an inactive and relatively sedate galaxy. Now however, the capabilities offered by the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) make it possible to conduct detailed comparisons of gas properties and interactions in the Milky Way center with those in other galaxy centers. Using new radio and millimeter observations of the Milky Way's Galactic center, this project will first make detailed studies of gas properties to constrain how accretion itself modifies gas conditions, and not just feedback from processes it drives (e.g., starbursts which are absent in the Galactic center). By relating the gas properties on sub-parsec scales determined by this study (scales that can only be probed in our own Galaxy center) to the properties on the parsec and larger scales, this work will test how well global properties probed in other galaxies represent the true properties on smaller scales. Ultimately, this project will directly compare the properties on parsec scales with new ALMA observations of the nearest starburst galaxy on identical parsec scales. Their work is the first 'apples to apples' comparison of detailed gas properties in galaxy nuclei: probing how interstellar medium properties change in the presence of a starburst, and advancing the understanding of our Galaxy center beyond a single case study. Finally, this program will produce a library of templates for the extreme gas properties in these nuclei that can be used to interpret conditions in distant, high redshift galaxies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Centers of galaxies are some of the most extreme environments in our universe, hosting supermassive black holes that weight millions to billions as much as our sun. Every galaxy like our own has a supermassive black hole in its center, yet we still know very little about how they gather gas from their surroundings to grow bigger. This is important because black holes are messy eaters, so when they are actively growing the energy they put out can impact the entire surrounding galaxy. Understanding their cycle of growth is essential to understanding how the Milky Way galaxy has been formed, and how future growth of its black hole might change our home galaxy in the future. To address these questions, researchers at the University of Kansas supported by this grant have assembled a unique sample of detailed observations of the molecular gas in several nearby galaxy centers, including the deepest and most sensitive 3 millimeter observation ever made, with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array. 

For decades, the only galaxy center where we have been able to study the gas with parsec-scale resolution is our own Milky Way. However our galaxy center is unusual for its low level of activity: the black hole is barely growing. It is necessary to study more active galaxies to test whether models of gas flow and evolution based on the present-day center of our Galaxy also apply to more active phases of galaxy center evolution. Researchers at the University of Kansas have addressed this challenge by making the first comparisons of the molecular gas (the fuel for future black hole growth) in galaxies on identical parsec size scales using identical tracers. This work has provided a new understanding of how a black hole’s future meals change as a function of time and environment. Measurements of a systematic increase in gas density as gas flows inward in the Milky Way (Mills et al. 2018), have shown that the gas flow becomes more concentrated with time as it approaches the central supermassive black hole. The first high-resolution look at gas in a nearby starburst galaxy, revealed an enhancement in gas turbulence in the center of NGC 253 compared to the Milky Way (Krieger et al. 2020), indicating that gas in an active environment is more disturbed. Finally, team has also identified individual star clusters in this galaxy responsible for driving a galaxy wind that may starve a black hole of its future meals (Mills et al. 2021, Levy et al. 2021).

The sample that has been assembled as a result of this grant will continue to be essential to disentangling the complex relationships between black holes, stars, and gas in the centers of galaxies to understand where our Milky Way fits in to a cosmic continuum of galaxy evolution. Work from this grant resulted in dozens of published papers, with more in progress.  Researchers supported by this grant also participated in teaching astronomy to an incarcerated student population. Instructional activities developed as a result of this work are publicly available in a GitHub repository: https://github.com/eacmills/intro-astro.

 


Last Modified: 03/29/2024
Modified by: Elisabeth A Mills

Images (1 of )
  • Example data (HCN 1-0) comparing the gas in nearby galaxy centers (observed with with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array) and gas in the center of the Milky Way (MOPRA telescope).
    Elisabeth Mills
    Copyrighted
    Elisabeth A Mills
    A High-Resolution Nearby Galaxy Sample
  • Observations of a dense gas-tracing molecule (HC3N), with the ratio of the two maps showing that the gas density increases substantially in the central degree of the Milky way, as it nears the supermassive black hole (marked with an X).
    Elisabeth Mills
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Elisabeth A Mills
    Increasing Gas Density in the Milky Way Center
  • The center of the nearby starburst galaxy NGC 253. An image of the 3mm continum emission, this is was the deepest ALMA exposure ever made.
    Elisabeth Mills
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Elisabeth A Mills
    ALMA Observation of a Nearby Starburst Galaxy
